abstract: The effect of water flow velocity and dissolved hydrogen on the deposition rate of Corrosion-Related Unidentified Deposit (CRUD) was investigated under conditions relevant to pressurised water nuclear reactors using type 304 l stainless steel micro-orifices. The results indicate that the CRUD build-up rate increases with hydrogen concentration because the amount of iron in solution also increases. At the same time, the fluid shear forces induce a mechanical removal of the oxide for flow velocities above 15 m/s. This suggests that the CRUD deposition process occurs under mass transport control, but the overall build-up rate is also affected by flow-induced mechanical removal.

author_highlights.sentence: CRUD build-up rate in accelerated flow regions was investigated with a microfluidic set-up.
Hydrogen increased the amount of iron in solution and the radial deposition rate.
CRUD deposition process occurs under mass transport control.
The overall build-up rate is also affected by flow-induced mechanical removal.
Higher CRUD build-up rate was observed in the low-velocity range 0–15 m/s.

body_text.sentence: A total of 35 water samples was extracted from the autoclave vessel using a Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) capillary line (see Fig. 1 (left)) that was inserted into an externally water-cooled stainless steel tube connected to the autoclave and coupled to a valve that was kept at room temperature.
body_text.title: Flow loop, instrumentation and methodology

body_text.sentence: Consequently, the distance that the particles need to travel to reach the surface decreases with increasing flow velocity and, as a result, the CRUD deposition is promoted.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: The mechanical drilling of the micro-orifices was carried out using the procedure described in detail in [22–24,29].
body_text.title: Test pieces description and test matrix

body_text.sentence: The water was circulated with a volumetric pump (flow rate up to 35 l/hrs) equipped with a pulsation damper to assure pulsation-free flow conditions during the tests and was preheated to the desired temperature with a preheater before being injected into the autoclave vessel.
body_text.title: Flow loop, instrumentation and methodology

body_text.sentence: The micro-orifice discs were cross-sectioned with a 3D Micromac (microPrep™1.1) laser ablation machine to characterise further the CRUD formed within and along the throat.
body_text.title: CRUD characterisation

body_text.sentence: In particular, for D300-0-[7-76], D300-0-[82-45], D300-0-[24-82] and D600-0-[6–16] the pressured drop was adjusted up to 5 times during the test allowing to characterise the build-up rate for several flow velocities during the same test.
body_text.title: Test pieces description and test matrix

body_text.sentence: It is worth noting that hematite is unlikely to form in the autoclave, even when hydrogen was not added, due to the low amount of dissolved oxygen in the water (<2 ppb).
body_text.title: Discussion

metadata.title: Deposition of corrosion products under pressurised water nuclear reactor conditions: The effect of flow velocity and dissolved hydrogen
